Description: Chinese stock market experienced a sharp decline, leading to global selloffs.
Global markets lost trillions due to concerns over China's economy and falling oil prices.
UK's vote to leave the EU caused immediate market turmoil and currency fluctuations.
Markets rebounded as central banks intervened and uncertainty eased.
Tariff announcements led to increased volatility and a year-end market correction.
Bitcoin and other cryptos plummeted, spilling over to tech stocks.
US-China Phase 1 deal boosted investor confidence and market highs.
Global pandemic fears caused the fastest bear market in history.
Stimulus packages and vaccine hopes drove a rapid rebound.
Retail investors drove massive gains in stocks like GameStop and AMC.
Inflation, Fed rate hikes, and geopolitical tensions led to a bear market.
Invasion caused energy price spikes and global market volatility.
Collapse of SVB and other banks triggered fears of financial contagion.
Surge in AI-related stocks like NVIDIA drove tech sector to new highs.
Japan's rate hike caused global selloff, worst since 1987 for some indices.
Sluggish recovery and real estate issues weighed on Chinese markets.
Trump's victory sparked gains in banks, crypto, and small caps.
Trump's second-term tariffs rose to 27% on average, increasing costs and volatility amid trade tensions with China and others.
Trump's new tariffs and China's retaliation led to a sharp global decline.
Announcements of potential 300% tariffs on semiconductors caused volatility in tech stocks like NVDA.
Escalating tariffs on Indian exports led to concerns over global supply chains and market dips.
